intro.description:
GitHub events are community events intended for networking and collaboration in the tech community.

We value the participation of each member and want all attendees to have an enjoyable and fulfilling experience. Accordingly, all attendees are expected to show respect and courtesy to other attendees throughout all events hosted in the GitHub space.

To make clear what is expected, all attendees, speakers, exhibitors, organizers, and volunteers at any event in the GitHub space are required to conform to the following Code of Conduct. Organizers will enforce this code throughout the event.

codeOfConduct.title: Code of Conduct
codeOfConduct.description: GitHub is dedicated to providing a positive and harassment-free event experience for everyone, regardless of age, gender, gender identity and expression, sexual orientation, disability, personal appearance, body size, ethnicity, race, religion, nationality, or level of experience. We do not tolerate harassment of event participants in any form, nor do we tolerate any behavior that would reasonably lead to another event participant being made to feel unsafe, insecure, or frightened for their physical or emotional well-being. All communication should be appropriate for a professional audience including people of many different backgrounds.

goodAndBadBehaviors.description: Examples of encouraged behavior that contributes to a positive environment include:
examples: Being respectful of differing viewpoints and experiences
Focusing on what is best for everyone at the event
The use of sexualized language or imagery, or inappropriate physical contact, sexual attention, or advances
Trolling, insulting or derogatory comments, personal or political attacks, or sustained disruption of talks or other events
Deliberate intimidation, stalking, following, or harassing photography or recording
Harassment of any kind, even in a joking or ironic manner
Other conduct which could reasonably be considered inappropriate in a professional setting

codeOfConduct.finalTips:
Be kind to others. Do not insult or put down other attendees. Behave professionally. Remember that harassment and sexist, racist, or exclusionary jokes are not appropriate at this event.

Each event guest is entirely responsible for their own actions.

Thank you for helping to make this a welcoming, friendly space for all.

reportingIncident.title: Reporting an incident
reportingIncident.description:
If you are being harassed, notice that someone else is being harassed, or have any other concerns, please contact the organizer by email (events@github.com) or phone/ text (+1 415 842 2837), or by speaking to another GitHub employee or a security officer.

GitHubbers will be happy to help participants contact security or local law enforcement, escort to safety, or otherwise assist those experiencing harassment to feel safe for the duration of the conference. We value your attendance.

credit.title: Credit
credit.description: Portions of this Code of Conduct are based on the example anti-harassment policy from the Geek Feminism wiki, created by the Ada Initiative and other volunteers, under a Creative Commons Zero license.

hero.lead: A virtual gathering for the maintainers who make open source possible.

newsletter.body: Be the first to know about Global Maintainers Summit news!
newsletter.label: Please enter your email

normalBlock.title: Open source project management is uniquely challenging and rewarding work.
normalBlock.description:
Calling all past, present, and future maintainers -—whether you're waiting for your first issue or you've triaged 2000 before lunch. Join us for honest talks and conversations on your challenges, triumphs, and projects.

While we spend lots of time in our own communities we rarely get the chance to get together with maintainers of other projects to laugh, cry, celebrate and share. At the Global Maintainer Summit, we’re taking the time to have those conversations and would love you to join us.

We’ll feature a wide variety of lightning talks on different projects’ approach to common problems. In between, we’ll chat with each other, and know we’re not alone in the issues we face.

Global Maintainer Summit is your chance to build collaborative relationships with other maintainers, cultivate new skills to reinforce your resiliency and avoid burnout, and explore solutions to the myriad of shared challenges maintainers face.

highlightedBlock.title: Let’s get vulnerable
bulletPoints:
What is it possible to automate,
and what will always need to be hand–crafted?

When it comes to contributors,
when do you accept help and when do you say no?
Is it possible to (gasp) take a vacation?

When everything was on fire,
how did you put out the flames?
highlightedBlock.description:
We’ll tackle all that, and much more.

We’re here for each other, us maintainers.

followEvent.title: Follow the event
followEvent.lead: Open source maintainers joining you live from all around the world.
followEvent.description: During the event we'll be hosting a virtual hallway experience in Gather. Jump in to explore and to talk with those standing closest to you, focusing on smaller or personal conversations.

calendarEvent.title: Global Maintainer Summit
calendarEvent.description:
A virtual gathering for the maintainers that make open source possible

https://globalmaintainersummit.github.com/

profile.name: Ashley Williams
profile.bio: Rust Foundation Exectutive Director. @rustlang core, rustWASM working group, and formerly @nodejs director.

project.name: Rust
project.description: Rust, the programming language, not a brutal survival video game or the reaction of iron and oxygen in the catalytic presence of water or air moisture.

_data.talkTitle: Title TBD on the creation of the Rust Foundation

profile.name: Paulus Schoutsen
profile.bio: Paulus Schoutsen is the founder of Home Assistant. He founded the company Nabu Casa, which employs him and 12 others to work full-time on open-source projects like Home Assistant and ESPHome to make privacy focused home automation accessible to everyone.

project.name: Home Assistant
project.description: Open source home automation that puts local control and privacy first. Powered by a worldwide community of tinkerers and DIY enthusiasts. Perfect to run on a Raspberry Pi or a local server.

_data.talkTitle: Staying afloat running a big open source project

profile.name: Brandon Roberts
profile.bio: Brandon is a Developer Advocate, focused on community engagement, content creation, and collaboration. Brandon enjoy learning new things, helping other developers solve problems, and contributing to open source. Brandon is a GDE, technical writer, and a maintainer of the NgRx project.

project.name: NgRx
project.description: NgRx is a framework for building reactive applications in Angular. NgRx provides libraries for global and local state management, isolation of side effects, and developer tooling to enhance application development.

_data.talkTitle: All PR's welcome! ...for now: the evolution of contribution standards as our project grew

profile.name: Brendan Burns
profile.bio: Brendan Burns is a co-founder of Kubernetes, and an emeritus steering committee member. His most recent work is on client libraries for working with the Kubernetes API, where he's a contributor and an active maintainer. Over the course of more than two decades in open source, he has maintained projects as diverse as the JMeter load testing tool, the DroidDraw WYSiWYG designer for Android and a port of the Quake II to Linux.

_data.talkTitle: Every order of magnitude the problem changes - Scaling Kubernetes from a single office to the world.

profile.name: Bartłomiej Płotka (Bartek)
profile.bio: Bartek Plotka is an engineer, the co-author of the CNCF Thanos project and the core maintainer of various open-source projects including Prometheus. He enjoys building OSS communities and maintainable, reliable distributed systems, ideally in Go. On top of that, he is active in the CNCF SIG Observability as the technical lead. He writes a book with O'Reilly.

project.name: Prometheus
project.description: Prometheus is an open-source systems monitoring and alerting toolkit originally built at SoundCloud. Since its inception in 2012, many companies and organizations have adopted Prometheus, and the project has a very active developer and user community. It is now a standalone open source project and maintained independently of any company. To emphasize this, and to clarify the project's governance structure, Prometheus joined the Cloud Native Computing Foundation in 2016 as the second hosted project, after Kubernetes.

_data.talkTitle: Should I merge this feature? Avoiding Hidden Cost of Extra Code or Blocking Users

profile.name: Eileen Uchitelle
profile.bio: Eileen M. Uchitelle has been contributing to the popular web framework Ruby on Rails since 2014 and has been a maintainer on the Core team since 2017. She is passionate about making Rails scalable, resilient, and secure while striving to always make user-friendly public APIs.

project.name: Ruby on Rails
project.description: Rails is a web application framework running on the Ruby programming language.

_data.talkTitle: Bug Report or Help Request? Tools and techniques for telling the difference

profile.name: Helen Hou-Sandí
profile.bio:
Helen is the Director of Open Source Initiatives at 10up and a Lead Developer for the WordPress open source software project. From her start as a PHP/MySQL applications developer to focusing on "the front-end of the back-end" from both the development and UX perspectives, she has a knack for figuring out what people need to get things done on their websites, including most recently on the relaunch of WhiteHouse.gov for the Biden-Harris Administration.

Although she never knows whether to tell people she's a New Yorker or from Virginia Beach, today Helen is based in San José, Costa Rica with her husband, two kids, and their very close-knit extended family. When not at the computer or hanging out with said family, she can be found at the piano or posting pictures of food she's making.

project.name: WordPress
project.description: WordPress is an open source web publishing platform, now powering more than 41% of the web. In addition to the 18 year old core software, it is the center of a bustling consumer and developer ecosystem, with tens of thousands of plugins and themes available and a healthy commercial market. While WordPress (in)famously does not run its entire development lifecycle on GitHub or even Git, today more and more parts are managed outside of the traditional Trac+SVN workflow.

_data.talkTitle: You Can't Have a Solution Without a Problem

profile.name: Hong Phuc Dang
profile.bio: Founder @FOSSASIA , Board Member @osballiance , VP @OpenSourceOrg , working on Inner Source at ZalandoTech on @eventyay and @pslabio

project.name: Eventyay
project.description: The Open Event Server enables organizers to manage events from concerts to conferences and meet-ups. Developed in conjuntion with the large open source conference FOSSASIA.

profile.name: Ifiok Jr.
profile.bio: Ifiok Jr. is a polyglot software developer based in Swansea, Wales. He is a maintainer for remirror.

project.name: remirror
project.description: remirror is a ProseMirror toolkit for React

profile.name: Lorena Mesa
profile.bio: Political scientist turned coder, Lorena Mesa is a data engineer, Director & Chair of the Python Software Foundation, JOSS editor, and PyLadies Chicago co-organizer. Lorena's time at Obama for America and her subsequent graduate research required her to learn how to transform messy, incomplete data into intelligible analysis on topics like predicting Latinx voter behavior. It's this unique background in research and applied mathematics that drove Lorena to pursue a career in engineering and data science. One part activist, one part Star Wars fanatic, and another part Trekkie, Lorena abides by the motto to "live long and prosper".

project.name: PyLadies
project.description:
PyLadies is an international mentorship group for marginalized genders, such as but not limited to non-binary people, trans people, and women in tech.

We host monthly events, talks, and study groups where you can meet other pythonistas and learn more about programming, data science, web development, and more.

_data.talkTitle: Building a Global PyLadies Community with GitHub Actions

profile.name: Mariatta Wijaya
profile.bio:
Mariatta is a Python core developer based in Vancouver, Canada. She focuses on Python core-workflow, documentation, and community-building.

She's currently working to get the Python Documentation Work Group off the ground, and has started doing Open Source Diary video series on YouTube.

project.name: Python
project.description: Python is one of the most popular programming languages. It is #2 on the TIOBE index as of May 2021.

profile.name: Mike McQuaid
profile.bio:
Mike McQuaid, Homebrew Project Leader?

Editor's note: I asked Mike for a very short bio and to his credit, he delivered.

project.name: Homebrew
project.description: Homebrew is an open-source package manager for macOS (and Linux)

_data.talkTitle: Robot Pedantry, Human Empathy: Automation and Homebrew

profile.name: Myles Borins
profile.bio: Myles Borins is a developer, musician, artist and maker. They work at GitHub as an Open Source Product Manager, is a Technical Steering Committee member of the Node.js project, and a board member of the OpenJS Foundation. Myles cares about the open web and healthy communities.

project.name: node.js
project.description: Node.js is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome’s V8 JavaScript engine. It has wide adoption ranging from corporate production use cases to education and the arts.

_data.talkTitle: Operationalizing and Scaling Release Management in the Node.js Project

profile.name: Chrissy LeMaire
profile.bio: Chrissy is a Cloud and Datacenter Management Data Platform MVP who has worked in IT for over 20 years. She is the creator of the popular SQL PowerShell module dbatools, holds a master's degree in Systems Engineering and is coauthor of Learn dbatools in a Month of Lunches.

project.name: dbatools
project.description: dbatools is an automation toolkit for Microsoft SQL Server that is known for being powerful, fun and easy-to-use. The project introduced a number of people within the Data Platform community to both open source and GitHub.

profile.name: Rose Judge
profile.bio: Rose is an Open Source Engineer who co-maintains Tern, an Open Source container inspection tool that creates a Software Bill of Materials for a given container. Besides driving the project forward, her goals as a maintainer are to help open source newbies get their first pull request merged and grow the contributor community around Tern. When she’s not chasing her dog or son around the house, you can find her running, baking, reading or napping.

project.name: Tern
project.description: Tern is an Open Source container inspection tool that creates a Software Bill of Materials for a given container.

_data.talkTitle: Letting them down easy: How to nicely say "no" to unwanted change proposals

profile.name: Keeley Hammond
profile.bio: Keeley Hammond (she/her) is an Electron maintainer and a senior software engineer at Slack. She is based in Portland, OR. When not working on Electron, Keeley volunteers for Women Who Code Portland and spends as much time as possible with her dog, Luna.

project.name: Electron
project.description: Electron is a framework that allows developers to create native applications with web technologies. Built with C++, Chromium and Node.js, Electron apps build and run on Mac, Windows, and Linux. Electron powers some of your favorite apps, like VSCode, Slack, Figma and Signal.

_data.talkTitle: Measuring Electron: Setting Project OKRs -- Actually No, it's about Pokemon Bots

profile.name: Angie Byron
profile.bio: Angie Byron is a core committer and product manager for the Drupal project. She got her start as a Google Summer of Code student in 2005, and since then has completely immersed herself in contributing to open source, and empowering others to do so as well. Her work includes strategic initiative coordination, user experience improvements, patch review, quality assurance efforts, and general community cat herding.

project.name: Drupal
project.description: Drupal is a free and open source content management framework which powers over 13% of the top 10,000 websites worldwide. It sports features such as a modular architecture, first-class accessibility, a sophisticated API for developers, but also sports a robust user interface to perform detailed configuration which requires no programming knowledge. Its community consists of over 1.39 million members, over 120,000 of those actively contributing.

_data.talkTitle: Collaboration Needs of Massive Open Source Communities
